biases.title: Perceptual Completion Bias
biases.definition: The tendency to fill in missing information with what we expect rather than what’s actually there.

biases.title: Consensus Proximity Bias
biases.definition: The belief that people physically closer to us are more likely to share our opinions.

biases.title: Effort Justification Drift
biases.definition: Gradually overvaluing outcomes that required sustained, rather than initial, effort.

biases.title: Temporal Framing Bias
biases.definition: Judging identical events differently depending on whether they’re framed as happening soon or later.

biases.title: Narrative Closure Bias
biases.definition: Preferring explanations that make a story feel complete, even when evidence is inconclusive.

biases.title: Salience Anchoring
biases.definition: Fixating on the most noticeable aspect of a situation and adjusting all later judgments around it.

biases.title: Expectation Gradient
biases.definition: Overestimating how quickly reality will align with our expectations once we take action.

biases.title: Cognitive Reciprocity Bias
biases.definition: Assuming that others think about us with the same intensity that we think about them.

biases.title: Authenticity Projection
biases.definition: Believing that our own sincerity is automatically apparent to others.

biases.title: Resolution Bias
biases.definition: The mistaken belief that identifying a problem is equivalent to having solved it.

biases.title: Confirmation Bias
biases.definition: Tendency to seek or interpret information in ways that confirm existing beliefs.
biases.reference: Nickerson, R. S. (1998). Confirmation Bias: A Ubiquitous Phenomenon in Many Guises. Review of General Psychology, 2(2), 175–220.

biases.title: Anchoring Bias
biases.definition: Relying too heavily on the first piece of information encountered when making decisions.
biases.reference: Tversky, A., & Kahneman, D. (1974). Judgment under Uncertainty: Heuristics and Biases. Science, 185(4157), 1124–1131.

biases.title: Availability Heuristic
biases.definition: Estimating likelihood based on how easily examples come to mind.
biases.reference: Tversky, A., & Kahneman, D. (1973). Availability: A Heuristic for Judging Frequency and Probability. Cognitive Psychology, 5(2), 207–232.

biases.title: Hindsight Bias
biases.definition: Believing, after an event, that it was more predictable than it actually was.
biases.reference: Fischhoff, B. (1975). Hindsight ≠ Foresight: The Effect of Outcome Knowledge on Judgment under Uncertainty. Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Perception and Performance, 1(3), 288–299.

biases.title: Dunning–Kruger Effect
biases.definition: People with low ability often overestimate their competence; experts may underestimate theirs.
biases.reference: Kruger, J., & Dunning, D. (1999). Unskilled and Unaware of It. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 77(6), 1121–1134.

biases.title: Loss Aversion
biases.definition: Losses feel more painful than equivalent gains feel rewarding.
biases.reference: Kahneman, D., & Tversky, A. (1979). Prospect Theory: An Analysis of Decision under Risk. Econometrica, 47(2), 263–291.

biases.title: Status Quo Bias
biases.definition: Preferring things to remain as they are, even when change may offer benefit.
biases.reference: Samuelson, W., & Zeckhauser, R. (1988). Status Quo Bias in Decision Making. Journal of Risk and Uncertainty, 1(1), 7–59.

biases.title: Framing Effect
biases.definition: Choices are influenced by how options are presented rather than by the facts themselves.
biases.reference: Tversky, A., & Kahneman, D. (1981). The Framing of Decisions and the Psychology of Choice. Science, 211(4481), 453–458.

biases.title: Sunk Cost Fallacy
biases.definition: Continuing a course of action because of past investment, not current value.
biases.reference: Arkes, H. R., & Blumer, C. (1985). The Psychology of Sunk Cost. Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes, 35(1), 124–140.

biases.title: Fundamental Attribution Error
biases.definition: Attributing others’ actions to character rather than situation, while excusing our own as circumstantial.
biases.reference: Ross, L. (1977). The Intuitive Psychologist and His Shortcomings: Distortions in the Attribution Process. In L. Berkowitz (Ed.), Advances in Experimental Social Psychology (Vol. 10, pp. 173–220). Academic Press.
